headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vic
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Davis, you may begin.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sayyid, and Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's second quarter 2015 results released earlier this afternoon. The slide presentation, we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today'
componenttext:
Thank you, Sayyid, and Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's second quarter 2015 results released earlier this afternoon. The slide presentation, we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today's call. It's available in the Investor Relations section of our corporate website at ir.centurylink.com. At the conclusion of our prepared remarks today, we will open the call for Q&A. 
As you move to Slide 2, you'll find our safe harbor language. We will be making certain forward-looking statements today, particularly as they pertain to guidance for our full year and third quarter 2015 as well as other outlooks in our business. We ask that you review our disclosure found on this slide as well as in our press release and in our SEC filings, which describe factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected by us in our forward-looking statements. 
We ask that you also note that our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon and the slide presentation and remarks made during this call contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliation between the non-GAAP financial measures and the GAAP financial measures are available in our earnings release and on our website at ir.centurylink.com. 
Now as you move to Slide 3, your host for today's call is Glen Post, Chief Executive Officer and President of CenturyLink. Joining Glen will be Stewart Ewing, CenturyLink's Chief Financial Officer; and also available during the question-and-answer period of today's call will be Ross Garrity, CenturyLink's interim President of Global Markets. Our call today will be available for telephone replay through August 13, 2015, and the webcast replay of our call will be available through August 27, 2015. Anyone listening to a taped or webcast replay or reading a written transcript of this call should note that all information presented is current only as of August 5, 2015, and should be considered valid only as of this date, regardless of the date heard or viewed. 
As we move to Slide 4, I'll now turn the call over to Glen Post. Glen?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and thank you for joining our call today as we discuss our second quarter 2015 results of operations, provide guidance and outlook for the second half 2015. Before we get into the details of the quarter, I want to highlight a few items th
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and thank you for joining our call today as we discuss our second quarter 2015 results of operations, provide guidance and outlook for the second half 2015. Before we get into the details of the quarter, I want to highlight a few items that I think are important to keep in mind as we go through our results. First, on the revenue side, our second quarter results were negatively impacted by renegotiation of a long-term wholesale agreement to reduce strategic revenue by about $13 million for the quarter and is driving an approximately $40 million reduction on our revenue outlook for full year 2015. This renegotiated agreement locks into those agreements at market rates for several years, giving us greater ability to grow that business and provide reciprocal access to our wholesale partners network at more attractive rates. We're revising our full year revenue midpoint to $17.8 billion, [ph] reflecting the impact of this wholesale issue and the full year effect of softer-than-expected for first-half results. Our revised guidance is approximately $45 million below the current consensus Street estimate of $17.85 billion, and $40 million of that is associated with a wholesale issue we're just talking about. 
However, the bigger issue in the second quarter was really expense. We had a number of noncore items that drove our expenses higher in the quarter, including $20 million in group insurance and pension true-up adjustments, and $20 million due to higher-than-expected CPE sales. The balance of our average is primarily due to not hitting the operating budgets we established for business units for the quarter, principally due to higher than anticipated employee-related costs. We do not believe this mess reflects anything fundamental in the cost structure of our business. Basically, we just didn't get the job done here. We have made a number of key changes, and as we will discuss later, we have put plans in place to address this issue in the second half of the year. 
Beyond 2015, we believe we have further opportunity to continue to align the cost in our business without revenue performance, and we will discuss some of this with you later in the call. I wanted to share with you -- this with you at the outset of the call, because I want to be clear that although our second quarter results did not  meet our expectation, I am as confident as I've ever been that we have the assets, products, the services and the opportunities required to grow our business. 
Now if you will turn to Slide 6, we believe several key priorities will drive future growth and profitability of our business. The first is to grow business revenues, driven principally by increased market penetration of our network and hosting, cloud and IP solution service offerings. With respect to our business network services, we continue to see strong demand from business, wholesale and government customers for high-bandwidth data services such as Ethernet, MPLS and Business GPON, and we're investing in aligning our operations to take greater advantage of this opportunity. 
Let me give you a few examples of what we're doing. As of June 30, we have made fiber-based GPON available to approximately 475,000 business locations, and we expect to add GPON service to another 25,000 businesses by year-end. There's good demand to this product, and given our relatively low penetration, we believe we have strong upside with those investments. 
We also continue to enhance our core network offerings, including next-generation MPLS and SIP trunking services as well as plans to enable software-defined networking and network functions virtualization capabilities into 43 data centers by the end of this year. 
During the first half of the year, we expanded our global data center footprint through expansion in the 6 markets, adding -- we added 10.8 megawatts of capacity -- critical capacity, and that brings CenturyLink's global data center capacity to more than 185 total megawatts across our 59 data centers. We still have upside in our existing data center investment as we had over 35% of sellable floor space available as of June 30. 
Our revenues from our CenturyLink Cloud platform is growing rapidly, more than doubling the last 12 months. Actually, 138% growth in the second quarter of last year. A primary focus in the cloud and hosting space is to strengthen our private and dedicated hosting capabilities. These private platforms required much of the automation and management tools as you see in major public cloud platforms. But our focus is on leveraging the CenturyLink cloud platform to enhance our enterprise customers the ability to turn up and manage both network and hosted workloads in private, dedicated environments, including the enablement of environmental services later this year. However, overall, we have not met our expectations in our managed hosting business. I believe our sales force drill organization contributed to this issue, but I believe the principal driver is in the latter part of 2014 and early 2015. We defocused our delivery of services on our existing managed platform to focus instead on putting workloads in the CenturyLink Cloud platform. The CenturyLink Cloud platform is a powerful and dynamic platform, but does not yet support all the functionality our managed hosting customers require. That defocus away from legacy platform was a misstep and has affected our hosting results, and we believe we can improve these results by refocusing on delivering services at increasing capabilities of our legacy platform, while we continue to enhance the depths of CenturyLink Cloud capabilities. 
Finally, we are also see good interest in our IT services, data analytics and service offerings. Our focus in this area is to provide targeted service to business customers who are underserved by the traditional larger system integrators. Although it's growing rapidly, this business is small in scale today, but the service offerings give us a good low capital-intensive opportunity to engage at the sea level and generate leads in the other parts of our business. This capability provides differentiating NDN solutions, including IT consulting, has led to a number of recent wins for CenturyLink to provide a large portion, or in some cases, all communications, data and IT services for those customers. 
Overall, in our Business segment, we have to improve our execution, but we are seeing strength in our sales momentum. For example, second quarter 2015 sales to our enterprise customers were up 10% from first quarter 2015 and up 16% from second quarter 2014, while our commercial sales increased 27% from second quarter of 2014. 
Continuing now on to Slide 7 and turning to the Consumer segment. We continue to see good results from those markets. We have deployed higher broadband speeds in Prism TV services. Specifically, in our GPON markets, the take rates continue to be strong and are exceeding our expectations. And because GPON is such a great driver of demand and penetration, we continue to expand our gigabit footprint and ended the quarter with more than 600,000 households and 16 markets having access to gigabit speeds. We expect to have gigabit service available to approximately 700,000 households by year-end 2015, with plans for further expansion thereafter. We're also trending technologies that enable us to 200 megabits over our legacy copper networks. This is an early stage -- in the early stages, but it is showing good promise. 
We're also expanding our Prism TV service in the second quarter, turning services in Portland, Salt Lake and many outlets. We had a total of 175,000 addressable homes in the second quarter, ending the quarter with over 2.6 million Prism TV addressable households. We anticipate expanding Prism TV services to another -- approximately 250,000 additional households due the remainder of 2015, and to reach more than 2.8 million total Prism TV addressable homes by year-end. 
Now in addition, we're developing an over-the-top offering that we'll be able to provide a robust, competitive video offering for customers both within and outside our Prism TV market footprint. 
And finally, we're tightening our credit policies for Internet-only customers to reduce sales to customers who tend to change Internet providers frequently, leaving unpaid balances when they exit. While we expect this change to negative impact consumer broadband net subscriber additions to the remainder of 2015, we anticipate this adjustment will actually help improve our broadband growth in 2016 due to lower churn. This move is unrelated to and have no impact in our marketing initiative for lower-income consumers in the CenturyLink Internet Basics program. We remain totally committed to offering affordable broadband access to lower-income households across our broadband service areas. 
Now on to discuss our thoughts around expense control. As I noted above, the principal issue for us this quarter was that our expenses were about $80 million more than we anticipated. About half of that amount is attributable to not managing cost through established budget. We can, we will do on this front. For starters, we're implementing plans to reduce planned operating expenses by approximately $125 million in the second half of 2015, including lowering contract labor, professional services cost, a reduction in the number of employees and other expense reductions. This is not simply to get target. We already have plans in place to address most of that number. 
Also independent of any news around second quarter expense, earlier this year, we established a dedicated team, whose sole purpose is to identify and drive ongoing efficiencies under our business. This team is reviewing every major process and every significant system to validate its business purpose, and whether there is a faster, better way to achieve that objective. An example of their work is the recent access in improving service intervals by more than 40% by streamlining processes. This relates to a better customer experience, the need for pure employees to perform that work and better margins on that business. We believe there are other opportunities similar to this as well as the opportunity to improve efficiencies by driving additional automation and simplification into business. 
Continuing on to Slide 8 now. Lastly, I'd like to take a minute to discuss our philosophy about our dividend. Given that our past revenue EBITDA growth is taking longer than we originally anticipated, and that our cash taxes are expected to increase significantly in 2016, we understand the market's focus on the sustainability of our dividend. So I want to be clear here. While no company can credibly say they will never cut their dividend, we see the dividend as a fundamental part of our overall value proposition to shareholders. We believe the most financially prudent way to manage our business is to balance our investment philosophy with our EBITDA performance, so that we can sustain a reasonable return of cash to shareholders, while positioning the company for long-term growth. We believe we have a number of opportunities to manage our business in a way that supports the dividend as we work to capitalize on our growth prospects. 
First, we have made significant investments in our network and data center infrastructure over the last several years, and believe we have the flexibility to lower our planned capital budget by about $200 million to approximately $2.8 billion [ph] for full year 2015, without significantly affecting our past growth. Also, I noted above, we have instituted plans to reduce our expense outlook by $125 million in 2015, and we have ongoing opportunities to increase efficiencies for automation, simplification and increased focus. However, we believe the most important thing we can do to sustain the dividend over the long term is to continue our path to revenue and EBITDA stability and growth. As I discussed above, we believe we have good opportunities to grow our business by driving greater penetration of products and services we have enabled over the last several years as well as implementing new services and capabilities we're in the process of rolling out. 
So the point I would like to leave you with is despite the wholesale issues in 2015 and lower than expected growth in certain of our strategic products, we believe we have the ability to grow our business and to balance our pursuit of growth with our ability to sustain our dividend. And our view is that managing our business to do this is a fundamental element of our value proposition to shareholders. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Stewart. Stewart?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Glen. I'll spend the next few minutes reviewing the financial highlights for the second quarter and then conclude my remarks with an overview of the third quarter and full year 2015 guidance we included in our earnings release issued earlier th
componenttext:
Thank you, Glen. I'll spend the next few minutes reviewing the financial highlights for the second quarter and then conclude my remarks with an overview of the third quarter and full year 2015 guidance we included in our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon. 
Beginning on Slide 10, I'll review some highlights from our second quarter results. I'll be reviewing these results, excluding special items as outlined in the earnings release, and associated financial schedules. 
Operating revenues were $4.42 billion on a consolidated basis, a 2.7% decline from second quarter 2015 operating revenues. Core revenue, defined as strategic revenue plus legacy revenue, was $4.02 billion for the second quarter, a decline of 2% from the year-ago period. Strategic revenues grew 1.9% year-over-year and represent 53% of total revenues compared to 50% a year ago. Strength in strategic products such as high-speed Internet, high-bandwidth data and Prism TV, continue to drive this growth as we added approximately 8,400 Prism TV customers during the second quarter. Based on our revised go-to-market strategy for consumer broadband that Glen discussed earlier, we would expect HSI net adds to be negative for the second half of the year. We generated operating cash flow of approximately $1.62 billion for the second quarter and achieved an operating cash flow margin of 36.8%. 
Year-over-year cash expenses were up primarily due to higher employee benefits, Prism TV and other costs, which were partially offset by lower customer premise equipment costs related to lower data integration revenues. 
Free cash flow was $562 million for the quarter. As a reminder, free cash flow is defined as operating cash flow less cash paid for taxes, interest, capital expenditures, along with other income. Our solid cash flows continue to provide us with the financial strength and flexibility to meet our business objectives and drive long-term shareholder value. 
Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the second quarter was $0.55. As we discussed on prior earnings calls, adjusted diluted EPS excludes special items and certain noncash purchase accounting adjustments, as outlined in our press release and associated supplemental financial schedules. Additionally, under the $1 billion share repurchase program, we repurchased 2.5 million shares for an investment of $90 million during the second quarter. Under the current program started in second quarter 2014, we have repurchased over 12 militants shares for approximately $460 million. Our level of share repurchases during the second quarter was lower than prior quarters due to strategic opportunities that prevented us from being in the market for several weeks and our being in a close window period since late in the quarter. Having moved past those strategic opportunities, we expect to continue to be opportunistic in completing this program within the 24-month period given the plan to set up a 10 B 5 1 program over the next few [ph] days to facilitate the purchase of shares through our third quarter earnings release day. 
Moving to Slide 11, in our Business segment. In second quarter, the Business segment generated $2.66 billion in operating revenues, which decreased $129 million or 4.6% from the same period a year ago. Second quarter strategic revenues for the segment declined 0.4% to $1.6 billion from second quarter 2014, driven by the decline the low-bandwidth data services and wholesale repricing, partially offset by the continued strength in high-bandwidth services such as MPLS, Ethernet and Wavelength. We continue to generate solid growth across enterprise customer market, and we see an opportunity for further investment in the small and medium-sized business space to improve market share and drive further growth. 
Our legacy revenues for the segment declined 7.7% from second quarter 2014 due primarily to a continuing decline in access lines. Total Business segment expenses increased from the year ago period, driven primarily by higher employee-related expenses. The segment margin of 42.6% decline from 45.6% a year ago. This decrease was primarily due to the continued decline in Business segment, legacy and low-bandwidth data services revenue along with higher operating expenses described. 
On Slide 12, I'll provide a little more detail on the revenue mix within the Business segment. High-bandwidth data services revenue grew $65 million or 10% year-over-year compared to second quarter 2014, driven by continued strength in sales to enterprise and government customers. While growth -- the growth rate remains solid for high-bandwidth services, it is somewhat dampened by slightly slower growth due to wholesale-renegotiated pricing for Ethernet backhaul services with a large carrier customer. Low-bandwidth data services, including private line, continued to decline in the second quarter. The year-over-year revenue decline of $81 million or 14% was primarily due to wholesale customers, network grooming efforts and migration of fiber-based services that we've experienced over the past year. We anticipate this level of year-over-year decline to improve over the coming quarters as we cycle through this period of higher disconnects. 
Hosting revenues declined $10 million or 3% from the prior year, driven primarily by unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately $6 million, customer credits and lower nonrecurring revenue compared to the year-ago period. 
In the second quarter, data integration revenues decreased approximately $44 million or 24% compared to second quarter 2014, driven by lower CPE sales. 
Now turning to Slide 13. Consumer generated $1.5 billion in total operating revenues, which was flat with the second quarter year ago. Strategic revenues in this segment grew 6.9% year-over-year to $758 million, driven by growth in high-speed Internet and Prism TV customers and select price increases. Legacy revenues for the consumer segment declined to 5.8% from second quarter 2014 as access line and long-distance revenue declines were partially offset by select price increases. 
Operating expenses increased $16 million or 2.7% compared to the same period a year ago to due to higher Prism TV costs. 
Now turning to Slide 14. For third quarter 2015, we expect operating revenues of $4.42 billion to $4.47 billion and core revenues of $4.02 billion to $4.07 billion and operating cash flow between $1.62 billion to $1.67 billion. Adjusted diluted EPS is expected to range from $0.53 to $0.58. 
Our anticipated sequential increase in third quarter operating revenues, core revenues and operating cash flow over to the second quarter results is primarily driven by growth in strategic services and select price increases. 
As outlined in our press release, we've revised our full year 2015 guidance to reflect year-to-date results as well as our stated expectations for the remainder of the year. For full year 2015, we expect operating revenues of $17.7 billion to $17.9 billion and core revenues of $16.1 billion to $16.25 billion. Both have been lowered, reflecting first half 2015 actual results along with continued pressure in wholesale private line, hosting and CPE revenues, along with the wholesale repricing previously mentioned. 
Operating cash flow is projected to be $6.7 billion to $6.85 billion and capital expenditures are projected to be approximately $2.8 billion or $200 million lower than our previous guidance of approximately $3 billion. 
As you know, on April 29, the FCC offered potential support payments to price cap carriers under Phase 2 of the Connect America Fund program, and carriers have until August 27 of this year to notify the SEC of their intention to accept or forgo the support in some or all of the eligible states. CenturyLink was offered up to $514 million in support across 35 states, and at this time, we expect to accept at least $300 million of the available support. We continue to evaluate the remaining support payments and expect the notify the SEC on or before the August 27 deadlines. We expect the FCC to begin distributions under the CAF II program in September or October of this year time frame, and expect the initial receipts to include incremental support that trues up the full year CAF II support we ultimately decide to accept to the full year frozen federal USF support that we received today. We expect minimal capital investments in 2015 related to CAF II due to timing of the program, but we do expect the full year of CAF II-related capital expenditures for 2016. We currently expect full year 2016 capital expenditures to be approximately $3 billion, inclusive of CAF II requirements, because of the significant investments we've made over the last several years that support our business plans for growth and position us to reallocate capital to CAF II. 
While any receipts from CAF II are not included in the updated guidance I discussed earlier, we did provide estimated ranges the potential impact on third quarter and full year 2015 guidance from the CAF Phase 2 support we ultimately accept and receive. We expect to recognize the full amount of CAF II support payments as other revenue in the year received. 
While we understand the scenario for focus for investors has been whether CenturyLink might implement some type of REIT structure, we've elect not to pursue that structure at this time for several reasons. These reasons include the competitive disruption of the transaction structure, the variety of opinions from investors and our lack of confidence that implementing such a structure would create real long-term shareholder value. 
Let me talk a little bit about cash taxes. In terms of cash taxes, we expect 2015 cash taxes to be $25 million to $125 million after considering approximately $150 million to $250 million of 2015 taxes that we expect to pay in March of next year. For 2016, we expect cash taxes to increase to the $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion range, including the deferral of the 2015 cash taxes in 2016 that I just mentioned. 
Recently, the finance committee passed a bill, Out Committee, that would extend the provisions that expire at the end of 2014, including bonus depreciation, retroactively for 2015 and through 2016. This 2-year bill was meant to push the issue beyond next year's elections. The Finance Committee Bill has not yet been considered by the full Senate. The Full House has currently extended some selective extenders, similar to what they did last year. Bonus depreciation has traditionally been one of these favorites of selective provisions. Congress went into their August recess last week, and the House and the Senate this week, so we don't expect any action on the extenders, at least until the fall. In the fall, we currently expect there to be negotiations and on the extenders, but given the support for bonus depreciation, we believe there's a very good chance that, again, is extended for at least 2 years through 2016. Should bonus depreciation that implemented only for 2015, we would expect our 2015 cash taxes to be approximately $25 million to $125 million and 2016 cash taxes between $550 million and $650 million after considering approximately $225 million to $300 million of 2015 taxes that we would expect to pay up in March of 2017 of. If bonus depreciation is extended through 2016, we expect our cash taxes would decrease by an additional $50 million to $150 million for 2016. So bonus depreciation can have a tremendous impact in our free cash flow. 
That concludes our prepared remarks for today. So at this time, I'll ask the operator to provide instructions for the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Gordon from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Gordon from Bank of America.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, we kind of gathered from the Analyst Day, it was going to be a tough quarter. So thanks, Glen, for kind of giving us that frank run down. I guess, Stewart, the way we are now is set up, we're kind of in the middle of the third quarter, the revenu
componenttext: I guess, we kind of gathered from the Analyst Day, it was going to be a tough quarter. So thanks, Glen, for kind of giving us that frank run down. I guess, Stewart, the way we are now is set up, we're kind of in the middle of the third quarter, the revenue and EBITDA guidance you're giving us, kind of a worst-case scenario, said that we're going to see flat revenues and rising margins. And at the midpoint of the guidance, it suggests we're going to see some pretty strong quarter-on-quarter acceleration in revenues and EBITDA growth heading into '16. And I guess, that's going to be big focus for kind of Glen's point about execution and such. So if we go to that Page 12, which is, really, I think on the business services side, and we look at that chart, can you kind of walk us through the pieces parts that are going to drive what you seem to think at this stage can still be strong revenue growth kind of heading into the back part of the year and into next?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So David, part of what's going to happen is one, we do -- we have adjusted some of our wholesale pricing. We think that will start picking up some orders from one of the major carriers that we've not really been picking up over the last 4 months or s
componenttext: Yes. So David, part of what's going to happen is one, we do -- we have adjusted some of our wholesale pricing. We think that will start picking up some orders from one of the major carriers that we've not really been picking up over the last 4 months or so. Additionally, we had a onetime item in the second quarter of about $13 million that we think we'll improve over the next quarter or 2. So -- and if you look at our EBITDA from a standpoint of fourth quarter -- third quarter and fourth quarter, particularly in the fourth quarter, we expect to have implemented some of the steps that Glen mentioned. And our expenses, actually from third quarter to fourth quarter, come down about $100 million or so. So that provides the higher margins that you'll see on the back half of the year. Additionally, we expect the second half of the year to continue to have good growth from the standpoint of our High Speed Internet revenue as well as private line, which is on the wholesale side.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, the second question is just on the CAF II piece. So I guess, if we take out $100 million from that kind of, I guess, $75 million from the midpoint of the EBITDA guidance, where we're reiterating the free cash flow guidance, so it sounds like
componenttext: And I guess, the second question is just on the CAF II piece. So I guess, if we take out $100 million from that kind of, I guess, $75 million from the midpoint of the EBITDA guidance, where we're reiterating the free cash flow guidance, so it sounds like with the CAF funding, actual EBITDA and free cash flow will probably end going up. But there's still this large gap that it seems you need to analyze over the next few weeks. I guess, that the key issue for people is going to be -- that the threshold for accepting the CAF money to make sure that it's accretive to the cash flow profile of the company rather than dilutive? And so that's the number that you're trying to figure out?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's what we're working through, David. And really trying to look at the effects on '16 and '17 of the CAF II monies. And we really are studying very hard the cost associated with building the network. And we think that if we're able to make some p
componenttext: Yes, that's what we're working through, David. And really trying to look at the effects on '16 and '17 of the CAF II monies. And we really are studying very hard the cost associated with building the network. And we think that if we're able to make some progress there, we can accept more of the CAF II monies. Basically, the minimum that we outlined in the release today really applies to about 24 states or so, or a couple of dozen states. And there are 11 other states that we're having to study a little bit harder in terms of where we are in terms with respect to the network and knowledge to build out with cost associated with those. So we could be slightly cash flow dilutive, but I mean, that is what we're trying to solve for.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simon Flannery from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simon Flannery from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: You have targeted 2015 as the year of revenue stability. You're not talking about getting to revenue stability long term. Is this something, where we think we can see revenue stability in 2016? Or is it going to take longer than that? And then on the divi
componenttext: You have targeted 2015 as the year of revenue stability. You're not talking about getting to revenue stability long term. Is this something, where we think we can see revenue stability in 2016? Or is it going to take longer than that? And then on the dividend, I appreciate the comments on how you're thinking about that in the color of the tax payments. But when you cut your dividends a couple of years ago, you did target or talked about bringing your payout below 60%. So how are you thinking about payout ratios, I guess, on a normalized cash taxes now? And if you get -- if the dividend payout rises above that level, how do you square those factors?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Simon, this is Glen. I'll take the first question regarding revenue stability. First of all, it's always will provide guidance for 2016 during our fourth quarter earnings call but based on the sales we're seeing today, the growth we're seeing in ours funn
componenttext: Simon, this is Glen. I'll take the first question regarding revenue stability. First of all, it's always will provide guidance for 2016 during our fourth quarter earnings call but based on the sales we're seeing today, the growth we're seeing in ours funnel, the expansion of our GPON the Prism footprint and capabilities, the expected improvement in our cloud and hosting and IT services products, I really believe we're going to see revenue stability in 2016 than what we're seeing right now.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Simon, in terms of the dividend payout ratio, of course, if we do get bonus depreciation, the dividend payout ratio will be approximately 60% or so in 2016 from what -- we -- from what we're seeing today. If we don't get bonus depreciation, really, it
componenttext: And Simon, in terms of the dividend payout ratio, of course, if we do get bonus depreciation, the dividend payout ratio will be approximately 60% or so in 2016 from what -- we -- from what we're seeing today. If we don't get bonus depreciation, really, it kind of depends on how much they get monies that we take and what were able to do with our capital budget. But we probably, for that 1 year 2016, would be in the 90% range or so. But that includes the tax payments of a couple -- $150 million or so, $150 million that we said we would be deferring to 2016 that really relate to '15. And also, we have $100 million pension payments scheduled in there as well that's not actually required. So we feel like we have some leverage that we can follow through, of course, our dividend payout ratio. So it's only about 45% or so, so we have plenty of room to bring the cash taxes for the if you wanted to get that out of '16. So I mean, we really feel comfortable that our levels, we can pull to the get our dividend payout ratio where it needs to be, to where it's not a problem, whether it's in '16. And again, assuming we get bonus depreciation, even for 1 year, it brings the 2016 dividend payout ratio down to around 60% range.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Phil Cusick from JP Morgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Phil Cusick from JP Morgan.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. First, on the CapEx reduction, can you expand on what's changing this year? Where can you cut without really impact the business at this point? And does the $3 billion guidance assume that, that follows through in 2016? Are you sort of
componenttext: A couple of things. First, on the CapEx reduction, can you expand on what's changing this year? Where can you cut without really impact the business at this point? And does the $3 billion guidance assume that, that follows through in 2016? Are you sort of pushing things out?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, some of the projects that we're looking at that we've actually got really relate to what we call =-- that falls in the revenue-enablement bucket, probably about a third of the cut is there. And these are projects that are really more network related
componenttext: Yes, some of the projects that we're looking at that we've actually got really relate to what we call =-- that falls in the revenue-enablement bucket, probably about a third of the cut is there. And these are projects that are really more network related that give us extra capacity, and we could go a little bit longer for that and related to that. And so we don't -- we may need to make some of those next year, but we think we can really pretty cut that. So about a third of the $200 million cost network-related. About a third of success base 2, which reduces just reflects -- although we're making our sales for and bookings for the second quarter, we're 15% ahead of where they were in the first quarter, there's still really behind where we originally expected when we set our capital budget for 2015. And another third of the $200 million is really cuts from -- comes from furniture equipment vehicles things and things like that, that we just think we cannot have to do. And some of that really relates to some of the other changes that we're making that Glen mentioned.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I just want to be clear on that. The $200 million we're cutting this year, we don't do not expect to add that to the budget next the year. We won't be doing that, so just to be clear on that.
componenttext: And I just want to be clear on that. The $200 million we're cutting this year, we don't do not expect to add that to the budget next the year. We won't be doing that, so just to be clear on that.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And again, the $3 billion next year really  includes CAF II, and that's why we'll go from like $2.8 billion to $3 billion. I mean, frankly, we're hopeful that next year, we can get our capital budget down potentially in the $2.5 billion to $2.6 billion ra
componenttext: And again, the $3 billion next year really  includes CAF II, and that's why we'll go from like $2.8 billion to $3 billion. I mean, frankly, we're hopeful that next year, we can get our capital budget down potentially in the $2.5 billion to $2.6 billion range, exclusive of CAF II.

componenttext: So on the buyback, can you remind us what the current authorization is? And any thoughts that the Board might accelerate that, given your confidence in revenue stability? And given where the shares are? And can you be just a little bit more specific on the cost items? What exactly are you focused on? And is it headcount related? And where -- and how that's going to come out as quickly as you've outlined it?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, Frank, so the Board authorized in February 2014 a $1 billion program. I think I mentioned we're about $540 million or so through that. And it expires in, essentially, May of 2016. And we would expect to complete the program -- our current plans are to
componenttext: So, Frank, so the Board authorized in February 2014 a $1 billion program. I think I mentioned we're about $540 million or so through that. And it expires in, essentially, May of 2016. And we would expect to complete the program -- our current plans are to complete the program by the [indiscernible] I mentioned, we expect to be back in the market next week and set up a 10 B 5 1 plan to start the process of repurchasing the remaining shares. With respect to the cuts, about 2/3 or so of the amounts are really related to contract labor and professional services as well as from employee cost and employee benefits. So that's where about 2/3 of it is. The other third is actually down and we think network expense as well as property taxes.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike McCormack with Jefferies.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Glen, can you just give a little more detail on, I think you mentioned credit policy changes. Just trying to get a sense if you're seeing a significant uptick in involuntary churn? Is that inside the Prism footprint, where you're getting people installed
componenttext: Glen, can you just give a little more detail on, I think you mentioned credit policy changes. Just trying to get a sense if you're seeing a significant uptick in involuntary churn? Is that inside the Prism footprint, where you're getting people installed and then sort of banning the equipment? And then I guess, secondly, in giving some thoughts to your comments regarding over-the-top, Prism TV probably is not as profitable as offering, obviously, straight broadband, although it might have churned reducing benefits, and we're seeing AT&T deemphasizing the U-verse platform. Does it make sense to sort of move away from Prism TV and focus more on developing the over-the-top products and getting just higher-speed data to the homes?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, on the credit policy change, we  -- that's mostly around just broadband, HSI. We have a little bit on Prism but more of HSI. We see a lot more churn there. No big churn, it is really more than previously. So we're -- that's really the reason. It's a
componenttext: Mike, on the credit policy change, we  -- that's mostly around just broadband, HSI. We have a little bit on Prism but more of HSI. We see a lot more churn there. No big churn, it is really more than previously. So we're -- that's really the reason. It's around high-speed data primarily. We're seeing that issuing, we're trying to address it. And regarding the Prism TV and over-the-top, certainly, the programming costs are high On Prism TV. have you looked at the all-in opportunity there, we would bring 52% of the new customs to CenturyLink, 57% are triple play customers, and about 97% of those customers have a high-speed data connection. So overall, these are profitable customers for us and we are pleased to get that we were working hard on the programming costs. This is a whole industry is and we think it's really an area that we have to change over time, but we think it is a good product for us and driving revenue and cash flows. The over-the-top is certainly an opportunity. We have some new products coming out over-the-top that we think will be very profitable and we're willing to include those with our Prism product as well as in areas we don't have Prism. And we think there's an opportunity there. Then you're right, they are higher margins within over-the-top product, and we're looking forward to offer that.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So with the states, where we would get -- if all we think is basically 2 dozen states or so, that results in about $300 million, there will be about $100 million of frozen support that we would continue to receive. At this point, we -- it just depends on
componenttext: So with the states, where we would get -- if all we think is basically 2 dozen states or so, that results in about $300 million, there will be about $100 million of frozen support that we would continue to receive. At this point, we -- it just depends on how long it takes the FCC to write the rules for the auction process and put that in place. And actually have the auctions, we believe the earliest that would be would be towards the end of 2016, but it could very well go over into 2017. And then we would also have the ability to be able to so participate in those functions as well. So about $100 million of frozen support board that we would continue to see in addition to the $300 million of CAF II funds.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. As we've called out today, we're not satisfied with our results for the quarter, and we have plans in place to correct that trajectory. But overall, I really believe we have the best portfolio of assets we've ever had in CenturyLink. Now
componenttext: Thank you, Steve. As we've called out today, we're not satisfied with our results for the quarter, and we have plans in place to correct that trajectory. But overall, I really believe we have the best portfolio of assets we've ever had in CenturyLink. Now it's really about execution. We're taking these assets and leveraging them to drive revenue growth, EBITDA growth and shareholder value over time. And while there certainly will be some quarterly ups and downs with some bumps in the road along the way, CenturyLink's long-term trajectory, in my view, is as positive and bright as it's ever been. So thank you for joining our call today, and we all look forward to speaking with you in the weeks ahead.
