headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to hand the conference over to Mr. Tony Dav
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to hand the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Said, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's Third Quarter 2015 Results released earlier this afternoon. The slide preservation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of the is ava
componenttext:
Thank you, Said, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's Third Quarter 2015 Results released earlier this afternoon. The slide preservation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of the is available in the Investor Relations section of our corporate website at ir.centurylink.com. At the conclusion of our prepared remarks today, we will open the call for questions and answers. 
ON Slide 2, you'll find our safe harbor language. We will be making certain forward-looking statements today, particularly as they pertain to guidance for fourth quarter 2015 and other outlooks in our business. We ask that you review our disclosure found on this slide as well as in our press release and in our SEC filings, which describe factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected by us in our forward-looking statements. We ask that you also note that our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon and the slide presentation and remarks made during this call contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliation between the non-GAAP financial measures and the GAAP financial measures are available in our earnings release and on our website at ir.centurylink.com. 
Now turning to Slide 3. Your host for today's call is Glen Post, Chief Executive Officer and President of CenturyLink. Joining Glen will be Stewart Ewing, CenturyLink's Chief Financial Officer; and also available during the question-and-answer portion of today's call will be Ross Garrity, CenturyLink's Interim President of global markets. 
Our call today will be available for telephone replay through November 12, 2015, and the webcast replay of our call will be available through November 26, 2015. Anyone listening to a taped or webcast replay or reading a written transcript of this call should note that all information presented is current only as of November 4, 2015, and should be considered valid only as of this date, regardless of the day heard or viewed. 
And as we turn to Slide 4, I'll now turn the call over to Glen Post. Glen?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and thank you for joining our call today as we discuss our third quarter 2015 results of operations and provide guidance and outlook for the remainder of 2015. Beginning on Slide 5, as you know, CenturyLink continues our transition to bec
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and thank you for joining our call today as we discuss our third quarter 2015 results of operations and provide guidance and outlook for the remainder of 2015. Beginning on Slide 5, as you know, CenturyLink continues our transition to becoming a leading provider of integrated IP-enabled network, hosting and IT services. This transition brings both opportunities and challenges as we work to find ways to provide our customers with product and services that they need in today's environment. Faster broadband speeds and hosting solutions are at the top of many of our customers' list of needs. We're deploying GPON to consumer and business customers. We're expanding Prism TV availability and providing competitive enhancements to our network, hosting and cloud services to meet these demands. 
In the third quarter, we saw several positive signs that we are making progress in this transition. First, the consumer segment had a solid quarter, with year-over-year revenue growth of 1.2% as we continue to deploy GPON and Prism TV to more locations throughout our footprint. We're attracting more high-value customers, and we have increased our ARPU through the continued launch of the GPON higher-value bundle sales and select pricing increases. 
Second, the business sales organization realignment implemented earlier this year is now proving effective as new sales-to-business customers for the third quarter increased year-over-year and sequentially. The third quarter marks the second straight quarter of accelerating sales with particular strength in global and enterprise. Additionally, in our business sector, we exited third quarter with a strong business sales bundle, including an increased number of large deal opportunities. 
You will recall last quarter, we stated that our operating expenses got ahead of our budget that you were committed to addressing that during the last half of the year. We're delivering on that commitment as we have taken steps to reduce planned operating expenses about [ph] approximately $125 million in the second half of 2015. We achieved a portion of this expense reduction relative to plan in the third quarter, but the majority of the benefit will be realized in the fourth quarter of this year. Also we're well on track to lower our full year 2015 planned capital budget by about $200 million, which will result in full-year capital expenditures of about $2.8 billion. We're encouraged by these areas, where we're seeing positive momentum. 
However, the overall revenue for our third quarter were below our expectations, primarily due to softness in hosting and long-distance service revenues along with higher credits and other onetime items in the quarter. If you normalize for the onetime items, the total about $20 million to $25 million, operating in core revenue for both at the low end our quarterly guidance range. Although our third quarter revenues results did not beat our expectation, I'm very confident that we have the assets and the products and the opportunities required to grow our business in the months ahead. 
Now turning to Slide 6. We believe several key priorities will drive future growth and profitability of our business. The first is to grow business revenues, driven principally by increased market penetration of our network, hosting, cloud and IT solution service offerings. With respect to our business network service offerings, we continue to see strong demand for business wholesale and government customers for high-bandwidth data services such as Ethernet, MPLS and business GPON. And we're investing and aligning our business to take advantage of this opportunity. This quarter, we saw continued strength in our sales momentum. Third quarter 2015 retail network sales were up approximately 15% from the second quarter of 2015, and up approximately 25% from the third quarter of 2014. Additionally, we exited the quarter with a strong business sales funnel. The sales funnel has continued to strengthen during fourth quarter, and October sales results were the highest of the year. 
I want to give you a few examples of what we're doing to drive higher sales over time. As of September 30, we have fiber-to-the-prem, including GPON, available to about 490,000 business locations. There is good demand for this product, and given our relatively low penetration, we believe we have strong upside for those investments. We also continue to enhance other core network offerings, including next-generation MPLS and sip trunking services and to add new capabilities to our Managed Office products suite to provide differentiated simplicity for smaller to medium businesses customers looking for fully outsourced network, customer premise equipment, cloud and business application solutions. We're also seeing increased interest in our managed network service offerings, that is, customers who look to us, not only to provide their connectivity, but also to manage their MD and network environment to include monitoring, security and CPE. Additionally, we have a major focus on leveraging our cloud capabilities to enhance our enterprise customers' abilities to turn up and manage both network and hosted workloads in private and dedicated environments. 
Over the last few months, we have refocused on our legacy cloud and managed hosting products as part of our hybrid IT strategy. We recently rolled out an enhancement of our legacy cloud products that seamlessly supports SAP workloads, and we have seen strong customer -- consumer -- customer interest, rather, in this product. 
We're seeing growing interest in managed hosting, legacy, cloud products, as our managed hosting funnel is up almost 60% since August. This funnel of growth is being driven by cross selling across our customer base, including state, government, education and a broad range of Fortune 500 and midsized companies. Finally, we're also seeing good interest in our IT services and data analytics service offerings. Our focus in this area is to provide targeted services to business customers, who are underserved by the traditional larger systems integrators. Although growing rapidly, this business is small in scale today, generating only about $15 [ph] million in revenue this year. But these services -- service offerings give us a good, low capital-intensive opportunities to engage at the CFO level and generate leads in the other parts of our business. This capability to provide differentiated end-to-end solutions, including IT consulting, has led to a number of recent wins for CenturyLink to provide a large portion on pontifications data and IT services for those customers. 
Now continuing on to Slide 7. Turning to the consumer segment, we continue to see good results in those markets where we have deployed higher broadband speeds and Prism TV services, specifically in our markets with fiber-to-the-prem, and including GPON, the take rates continue to be strong and are exceeding our expectations. And because GPON is such a great driver of demand and penetration, we continue to expand our gigabit footprint into the quarter more than 780,000 households and 16 markets that are now fiber-to-the-prem capable. We're also trialing technologies that enable up to 200 megabits over legacy copper networks. This is in the early stages, but it is showing good promise. 
We also expanded our Prism TV service to new and existing markets, adding a total of 360,000 addressable homes in the third quarter. We now have nearly 3 million Prism TV addressable homes, which exceed our expected target for the year as we pull forward some 2016 expansion plans into this year. In addition, we're developing an over-the-top platform and finalizing content agreements to enable our robust and competitive video offering for customers, both within and outside our Prism TV market footprint. And finally, we are focusing on driving improved operating efficiencies through a number of methods, including network simplification and rationalization that should improve our end-to-end provisioning time and help drive standardization. We continue our focus on improving back-office process at the systems in an effort to enhance customer experience and realize expenses efficiencies in running the business. 
We mentioned last quarter that we have reduced the provisioning time for one of our major by that approximately 40%, and since that time, we have implemented process and system changes to improve the provisioning time for another major product by 30% to 40%. We'll continue to enhance our efforts in this area as we evolve our back office systems to a more automated approach in the delivery of CenturyLink's products and services. 
In addition, we continue to drive network virtualization through our software-defined networks or SDN product and network function virtualization NFP capabilities. These enhancements allow customers to remotely establish and manage key network services such as virtual firewall, CDN and virtual network services. Our goal is to enable this capacity -- or this capability to 43 data centers and approximately 3.1 million businesses by year-end. 
We've also laid the foundation to migrate our internal IT operations to our cloud platform as we continue to invest in IT virtualization. We're continuing to use a cloud-first approach to rapidly deploy the same innovative platform infrastructure and Software-as-a-Service solutions across our internal IT operations that we're selling to our cloud and IT hosting customers. This effort is expected to reduce our IT cost and improve security and drive other efficiencies for us. 
Lastly, we continue to make progress in simplifying our process and streamlining our workflow. Our network inventory consolidation effort, which we have mentioned before, continues to progress well. Additionally, we have implemented an automated sales tool that increased our seller efficiency with anywhere, anytime access to our back office systems. This initiative has also improved our real-time tracking of opportunities associated results. 
Continuing on to Slide 8, I'd also like to briefly comment on the strategic alternative process from our data centers in colocation business operations that are announced today, CenturyLink's Board of Directors and management team regularly review the company's strategy and consider a wide range of opportunities regarding our business and operations to create value for shareholders. We believe we have the right strategy in combining our network service offerings with the delivery of managed IT and cloud-based services, and our enterprise customers are responding well to our managed service offerings. We expect colocation services will continue to be a service our customers will look to us for, but we do not necessarily believe we have to own the data center assets to be effective in the delivery of those services. Therefore, we have engaged financial advisers and we've initiated the process to explore those strategic options for our data center assets and operations, which includes 59 data centers in U.S., Asia and Europe, with more than 185 megawatts of power across 2.6 million square feet of raised four [ph] capacity. The review process will involve a full range of options, including but not limited to, a partnership or joint venture, a sale of all or a portion of the data centers as well as potentially keeping these assets and operations as part of CenturyLink's portfolio. This announcement continues our strategy of proactive portfolio management to drive focus on strategic businesses so we can achieve profitable growth and deliver attractive shareholder value. 
Now the process has just commenced, and we will not set a specific -- we have not set a specific timetable for a decision, but we will be updating you on this process as appropriate in the weeks and months ahead. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Stewart for a discussion of our financial results and guidance. Stewart?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Glen. I'll spend the next few minutes reviewing the financial highlights from the third quarter in the conclude my remarks with an overview of fourth quarter 2015 guidance we included in our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon.  Begi
componenttext:
Thank you, Glen. I'll spend the next few minutes reviewing the financial highlights from the third quarter in the conclude my remarks with an overview of fourth quarter 2015 guidance we included in our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon.  Beginning on Slide 10, I'll review some highlights from our third quarter hose results. I'll be reviewing the results, excluding special items as outlined in the earnings release and associated financial schedules. 
Operating revenues were $4.55 billion on a consolidated basis, a 9/10 of 1% increase from the third quarter 2014 operating revenues. The increase is primarily due to the incremental $158 million revenue impact from the acceptance and recognition of CAF Phase II funds in the quarter. Our core revenue, defined as strategic revenue plus legacy revenue, was $3.99 billion for the third quarter, a decline of 2.1% from the year-ago period. Strategic revenues grew 7/10 of 1% year-over-year, primarily driven by strength of the digital products such as high-speed Internet, high-bandwidth data and Prism TV. In the third quarter, we added approximately 11,300 Prism TV customers. High-speed Internet customers declined about 37,000, partially as the result of tightening our credit and collection processes. As a result of these actions, high-speed Internet and Prism TV that subscriber growth was negatively impacted. However, these adjustments had little impact on revenue and should actually help improve our broadband growth in 2016 due to lower churn. 
We generated operating cash flow of approximately $1.78 billion [ph] for the third quarter and achieved an operating cash flow margin of 39.1%. Cash expenses were nearly flat year-over-year, primarily due to lower customer premise equipment costs related to lower data integration revenues, which were partially offset by higher employee benefit expenses, Prism TV and other costs. Cash expenses declined $23 million from the second quarter 2015 as we took measures to reduce planned expenses in the second half of the year. Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow, less cash paid for taxes, interest and capital expenditures, along with other income, was $747 million for the quarter. Our solid cash flows continue to provide us the financial strength and flexibility to meet our business objectives and drive long-term shareholder value. 
Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the third quarter was $0.70. As we've discussed on prior and each calls, adjusted diluted earnings per share excludes special items and certain noncash purchase accounting adjustments, as outlined in our press release and associated supplemental financial schedules. 
Additionally, under the $1 billion share repurchase program, we repurchased 9.8 million shares for an investment of $263 million during the quarter. Onto the current program, starting in the second quarter of 2014, we have repurchased 27.5 million shares through November 3 and have approximately $133 million remaining under the repurchase program. 
Moving to Slide 11 and our Business segment. In third quarter, Business segment generated $2.64 billion [ph] in operating revenues, which decreased $137 million or 4.9% from the same period a year ago. Third quarter strategic revenues for the segment decreased 2.1% to $1.6 billion from third quarter a year ago driven by the declines in low-bandwidth data services, wholesale repricing and onetime items, partially offset by continued strength in high-bandwidth services such as MPLS, Ethernet and Wavelength. 
Legacy revenues for the segment declined 7.1% from third quarter 2014, due primarily to a continuing decline in access lines and lower long-distance revenues. Total Business segment expenses decreased from a year-ago period, driven primarily by lower CPE cost, partially offset by higher employee-related expenses. The segment margin of 41.5% declined from 44.1% a year ago. This decrease was primarily due to the continued decline in Business segment, legacy and low-bandwidth data services revenue. 
On Slide 12, I'll provide a little more detail on the revenue mix within the Business segment. Our high-bandwidth data services revenue grew $44 million or 6.7% year-over-year compared to third quarter 2014, driven by continued strength in sales to enterprise and governmental customers. While the growth rate remains solid for high-bandwidth services, it was somewhat dampened by renegotiated pricing for Ethernet backhaul services with a large wholesale data customer, as we discussed with you last quarter. High-bandwidth data services revenue for retail network customers, excluding wholesale, grew approximately 8.6% year-over-year. Our low bandwidth data services, including private line, continued to decline in the third quarter. The year-over-year decline of $68 million or 11.8% was primarily due to wholesale customers' continued network grooming efforts and the migration to fiber-based services that we have experienced over the past year. We anticipate this level of year-over-year decline to improve over the coming quarters as we cycle through this period of higher disconnects. 
Hosting revenues declined $7 million or 2.1% from the prior year, driven by the by higher credit reserves, including those related to service outages and an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately $6 million, which were partially offset by higher nonrecurring revenue. In the third quarter, data integration revenues decreased approximately $32 million or 17% compared to third quarter 2014, driven by lower CPE sales and maintenance revenues. And again, these revenues are fairly low margin. 
Now turning to Slide 13. Consumer generated $1.51 billion in total operating revenues, an increase of $18 million or 1.2% from third quarter a year ago. Strategic revenues in this segment grew 7.2% year-over-year to $763 million, driven by a year-over-year growth in high-speed Internet and Prism TV customers and higher average revenue for customer through select price increases and higher-value bundles. Legacy revenues for the consumer segment declined only 4.2% from third quarter 2014 as access line and long-distance revenue declines were partially offset by select price increases. Operating expenses increased $10 million or 1.6% compared to the same period a year ago due to higher Prism TV costs. 
Now turning to Slide 14. For the fourth quarter 2015, we expect operating revenues of $4.4 billion to $4.45 billion, core revenues of $3.97 billion to $4.02 billion and operating cash flow between $1.72 billion and $1.77 billion. Adjusted diluted EPS is expected to range from $0.62 to $0.67. Our anticipated sequential decrease in fourth quarter operating revenues and operating cash flow compared to the third quarter results is primarily driven by the retroactive recognition of CAF II funds in the third quarter. 
That concludes our prepared remarks for the day, so at this time, I'll ask the operator to provide instructions for the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Rollins.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Rollins.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was curious if you talk a little bit more about the thought process of pursuing strategic alternatives for the data center business? Firstly, if you dispose that, would that include the cloud and hosting business? Or will it be co-location only? Second,
componenttext: I was curious if you talk a little bit more about the thought process of pursuing strategic alternatives for the data center business? Firstly, if you dispose that, would that include the cloud and hosting business? Or will it be co-location only? Second, could you talk to us how much capital you put into that business to date, including the M&A? And then third, could you give us an EBITDA factor for that business in terms of the portion that you're pursuing these alternatives for?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, first of all, we're not ready to talk about the financials at this point. Obviously, we do disclose the revenue for this business as about $600 million annually today. And the sale of these assets do not include our cloud and hosting operations, str
componenttext: Mike, first of all, we're not ready to talk about the financials at this point. Obviously, we do disclose the revenue for this business as about $600 million annually today. And the sale of these assets do not include our cloud and hosting operations, strictly the data center operation, colo business itself. That's what we're selling and we are looking to sell, looking at alternatives, looking at what the best future use of these or management of these assets will be. So that's our view right now. We're just starting this process.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And can you just refresh our memory with how much of the assets that you physically own, maybe, versus those that you lease from third parties?
componenttext: And can you just refresh our memory with how much of the assets that you physically own, maybe, versus those that you lease from third parties?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, most of the assets are leased from third parties. We own several of the data center properties, but that's probably just guessing offhand, probably less than 10 or so. Some of the old Qwest data centers assets were primarily the ones that we own. Mo
componenttext: Mike, most of the assets are leased from third parties. We own several of the data center properties, but that's probably just guessing offhand, probably less than 10 or so. Some of the old Qwest data centers assets were primarily the ones that we own. Most of the others were leased.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last question. As you thought about pursuing strategic alternatives for this part of your business, did you evaluate pursuing strategic alternatives for any other parts of your business? Or is that something that you may consider in the future?
componenttext: Last question. As you thought about pursuing strategic alternatives for this part of your business, did you evaluate pursuing strategic alternatives for any other parts of your business? Or is that something that you may consider in the future?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. We continue to look at all of our assets and look at opportunities. For them, at least, the ones we believe or the ones we should take a look at. We may look a others in the future, but right now, this is the part of the business that we believ
componenttext: Yes, Mike. We continue to look at all of our assets and look at opportunities. For them, at least, the ones we believe or the ones we should take a look at. We may look a others in the future, but right now, this is the part of the business that we believe that is not necessarily important for us to own, so that's -- this is how we're looking at these assets as far as strategic alternatives are concerned.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Gordon from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Gordon from Bank of America.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, just as a follow-up on that, the $600 [ph] million colo business generates a 35% margin and it were to trade at the multiple, which Windstream recently announced their deal, maybe about $3 billion. And then if you took about half of that a
componenttext: I guess, first, just as a follow-up on that, the $600 [ph] million colo business generates a 35% margin and it were to trade at the multiple, which Windstream recently announced their deal, maybe about $3 billion. And then if you took about half of that and got back to the midpoint of your leverage range, you'd still have $1.5 billion. What would be your thought process in terms of priorities for allocating that money? 10% of the equity market cap, obviously, potentially creates a lot of options and it would be interesting to discuss. Second, if you could just kind of give us, more specifically, o $125 million cost cuts, what was in the third quarter? And obviously, then, what can we do in the math in the fourth quarter? And then the last piece will be, Stewart, just on those slides on 11 and 12, I mean, I think that there is a big debate around a company like CenturyLink and in particular, CenturyLink, if your revenues are coming down, you're having a tough time figuring out what's going to happen in revenue, we're having a tough time. But even tougher has been kind of trying to line up the margins with these different businesses to figure out what's important? CPE comes down, it's not important, but if legacy voice [indiscernible] is, can you put margins around these different buckets so that we could kind of do the math and figure out as we predict what's happening in the revenue decline, what's going to happen to margin decline?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the first question and then do the rest with the others. We're realizing there are a lot of good options for us to use proceeds from this if we were to end up selling these assets. We're leveraging them in a way to create more cash for the com
componenttext: I'll answer the first question and then do the rest with the others. We're realizing there are a lot of good options for us to use proceeds from this if we were to end up selling these assets. We're leveraging them in a way to create more cash for the company. But we're not ready to talk about those, they're pretty obvious health options we have. But we know that -- we believe that the opportunity is there and we will continue to work with our Board for the next few [ph] months to decide how to use those [indiscernible] proceeds..

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of the cost cuts, basically, we did a little bit better than we would expect to in the third quarter. But we expect fourth quarter cost to be down in the neighborhood of $100 million, [ph] which is the same amount we gave last quarter between
componenttext: So in terms of the cost cuts, basically, we did a little bit better than we would expect to in the third quarter. But we expect fourth quarter cost to be down in the neighborhood of $100 million, [ph] which is the same amount we gave last quarter between third and fourth. And part of that is seasonal, just related to the seasonality of the business and the rest of it really relates to CPE and some of the measures that we took to reduce our staff. So again, probably about another $100 million decline from third quarter sequentially in terms of cash operating expenses. In terms of the revenue trends and forecasting of the margins, based on an increase in sales funnel and improving sales trends over the last couple of quarters and our improving sales to revenue or order to cash, we hope to reach -- we expect to reach that revenue stability during the last half of '16. So we believe the pressure we're seeing in the last half of this year in hosting and wholesale will carry forward into the first half of '16, which will make the year-over-year revenue comps during that period somewhat challenging. Again, remember, we have the wholesale renegotiation of our contract to a large customer that will cycle through that after second quarter of next year. But unlike previous years, we don't think next year will be dependent on significant revenue growth for new initiatives to hit the revenue target in the second half of next year. In terms of margins, the margins in the consumer business have been relatively flat and we would hope to keep the margins there relatively flat to slightly down because we'll still see the cycling through of legacy revenue as we drop legacy revenue and replace it with a more strategic revenue such as our Prism TV product. And on the business side, basically, the margins there would expect to see some continued deterioration there due to really the same reasons associated with the loss of legacy revenue and replacing it with the strategic revenues at a lower margin. But we've also done a good shop there of controlling our expenses as well, which hopefully will mitigate some of the margin decline that we otherwise see.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Sameer from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Sameer from Barclays.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just following on some of the questions around your strategic alternatives that you're currently pursuing, can you provide us with a bit more color in terms of why you believe this is the opportune time right now to monetize sort of the co-location servic
componenttext: Just following on some of the questions around your strategic alternatives that you're currently pursuing, can you provide us with a bit more color in terms of why you believe this is the opportune time right now to monetize sort of the co-location services business? I would suspect that given the demand environment, there is healthy demand for those types of services, so would love to hear sort of your thought process on why this would be an opportune time. And I recognize that thinking about sort of specifics around what you can do with that capital building, on David's prayer question, it's probably a bit early stage right now. But as you look at your portfolio of assets today, how do you feel about the portfolio asset in terms of the growth opportunities? Because clearly, within the portfolio, there are some key growth opportunities and how should we think about whether or not there's a potential opportunity to bolt on additional assets or anything along those lines in order to accelerate growth towards your strategic services?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Amir, first of all, as you mentioned as [indiscernible] valuations are obviously good right now. As always, they can always change, but we think the market is good. But that's just one factor. For us to really grow the business, the colo business, is requ
componenttext: Amir, first of all, as you mentioned as [indiscernible] valuations are obviously good right now. As always, they can always change, but we think the market is good. But that's just one factor. For us to really grow the business, the colo business, is required with the more CapEx that we've been willing to put in the business. We set it up front. But the word invest heavily in the data centers, so we took a synergistic asset that we could grow with the rest of our business. However, with the valuations, with the -- we don't -- we think our cash flow could be used for investments that can drive higher returns, basically, and drive shareholder value. So that's why you we're looking at it. And we' don't think, as I mentioned earlier, that it's crucial for us to own these assets in order to provide a fall solution package for our customers. So that's why we're looking at it now. And as far as of the portfolio, we believe we have a strong portfolio of assets that we can leverage to drive future growth. We don't feel like we are compelled to go out and acquire additional assets or companies, however. We do believe there are some potential acquisitions and organic opportunities there that could drive growth. Whatever we do, continue to utilize our very disciplined approach to acquisitions and be sure that we believe their investments can really drive long-term shareholder value. So either in fiber assets, as it's perhaps drive top line growth that point be synergistic our other offerings such as our managed cloud offerings, our other Network Services that we believe we can grow with them on the head. So those are the type of opportunities for acquiring assets will be looking at.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And one follow-up, if I may. In terms of the operations, you folks had a transition a bit of your strategy with respect to your sales force in recent quarters. Would love to get an update in terms of how that transition has occurred? And in terms of the p
componenttext: And one follow-up, if I may. In terms of the operations, you folks had a transition a bit of your strategy with respect to your sales force in recent quarters. Would love to get an update in terms of how that transition has occurred? And in terms of the progress that you've made from that personally?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it was a pretty bumpy ride. We said upfront, it was not going to be -- we're going to have some issues with that. It lasted longer than we thought. However, if you look at our sales results, this last quarter specialty, the latter part of the second
componenttext: Well, it was a pretty bumpy ride. We said upfront, it was not going to be -- we're going to have some issues with that. It lasted longer than we thought. However, if you look at our sales results, this last quarter specialty, the latter part of the second quarter and going into the third quarter especially in the fourth quarter, we're seeing the benefits of those changes really come to fruition. So we believe it is -- we're proving that this one's the right move. And we are hoping [indiscernible] adjustments we'll make to really fine tune it, but we believe these were positive changes that are -- that we're going to see benefits from at the month and years ahead.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Simon Flannery from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: You touched on the revenue growth outlook. Can you talk a little bit about the competitive environment with cable, the broadband market, which is a little bit soft or the broadband is a little bit soft. What's going on there? Churn, gross adds? What can y
componenttext: You touched on the revenue growth outlook. Can you talk a little bit about the competitive environment with cable, the broadband market, which is a little bit soft or the broadband is a little bit soft. What's going on there? Churn, gross adds? What can you do to return to growth there? And also, maybe talk a little bit about in Prism, where you're talking earlier in one of the calls about cord cutting by the millennial-s and the move to over-the-top skinny any bundles, et cetera. Any thoughts on some of those offerings?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ross Garrity, talk about that for a minute for you.
componenttext: Ross Garrity, talk about that for a minute for you.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the consumer market, the competitive environment has remained fairly stable, but we've seen another round of speed increases coming from sort of cable provider from the cable providers, but we continue to see success in areas, where we've got greater s
componenttext: In the consumer market, the competitive environment has remained fairly stable, but we've seen another round of speed increases coming from sort of cable provider from the cable providers, but we continue to see success in areas, where we've got greater speeds, and we remain challenged in areas where we have the highest speeds. We are still continuing to see strong penetration velocity, especially in our GPON markets. And as for the small to medium business over the last 3 quarters, we've seen our investments' increased distribution and business GPON invest capability [indiscernible] Managed Office significantly improved their market share trends versus the cable providers. And we expect to see improving sales and market share trends in the segment certainly going into 2016. So I think the outlook is fairly positive.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Simon, I might add that the change that we made in the credit policies and really collections drove probably about 17,000 or so of the 27,000 decline that we saw -- or the 37,000 decline that we saw in high-speed Internet customer during the quarter.
componenttext: And Simon, I might add that the change that we made in the credit policies and really collections drove probably about 17,000 or so of the 27,000 decline that we saw -- or the 37,000 decline that we saw in high-speed Internet customer during the quarter. We are going to focus, really trying to penetrate the areas where we have rolled out GPON. We're also looking at other ways to improve our speeds, continuing to improve our speeds for copper. So I think that we'll be able to be remain competitive and hopefully become more competitive actually than we are today. We're also working on over-the-top offering that will be trialing third quarter that we hope to roll out on a trial basis in 2 to 3 markets latter part of this year and early next year that we think well help us with the millennials and be a lower-cost option from a standpoint of the way we roll it out in our Prism product is today.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Batya Levi from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Batya Levi from UBS.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: Can you address the slowdown in high-speed retail business revenues that we sold? I think it grew 8.6% versus a trend of double-digit growth. And what are you doing to accelerate that growth again? And second question on the CapEx, you pulled forward some of the spending in the third quarter. How should we -- and you maintained a guide for the year. How should we think about potentially different CapEx buckets for next year?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Batya, in the slow down of high-speed Internet revenue is, we actually had some pretty large federal items that flowed through in the first quarter and in the second quarter that didn't recur in the third quarter, so I think that's part of that. But pa
componenttext: So Batya, in the slow down of high-speed Internet revenue is, we actually had some pretty large federal items that flowed through in the first quarter and in the second quarter that didn't recur in the third quarter, so I think that's part of that. But part of what we're doing there, too, and on high-speed Internet and ethernet really, is, really pushing to reduce our provisioning periods like Glen spoke about earlier giving his part. In terms of CapEx for 2016, we're currently thinking about $3 billion, which will probably include $350 million to $400 million of CapEx associated with the roll out of the CAF II.

componenttext: Yes, frank, I have a few comments, then Stewart [indiscernible] strategic growth back up. If you look at the second half sales growth with expansion, it is creating some improving trends headed into 2016, so we think that's a sign. If you look at our sales that I mentioned earlier in the funnel, we think that's really a positive. We are seeing improvement in the front line sales productivity on the business side. We see a high participation rates or hitting our quotas basically. We're seeing growth in our channel partners and alliances there. We expect further growth there in the months ahead. But we're also expanding our product wholesale products to include HSI and a VoIP or voice over IP. So we expect to enhance our wholesale sales there and revenue. And finally, just the continued expansion of GPON and Prism. We've increased our GPON markets significantly this year of up to 7.8 [ph] million households past now. So it's -- we're seeing [indiscernible] 780,000 households past. And the expansion along with the business GPON up to about 490,000 businesses now. Those give us a lot of potential going forward.

componenttext: Yes, Frank, with respect to the CAF II deployment, we would expect to really have the ground running.an here in 2016 to late 2015 to 2016 to get some of the construction done and get the 11 units that are easiest to get to first such that by the end of'16, we hope to be upwards of 20% or maybe even a little more in terms of the 1.2 million living units past. So -- and some of those households will have more bandwidth than that, too, if they're closer to the node. So yes, the product will be available there, so we will have a video product in their.

componenttext: And on the right time between the fiber-to-the-node it's not fiber-to-the-node, we really don't break that out. But I can tell you, Mike, that our best penetration, really, in the markets where we have the higher speeds, and that's why we're focused on investing more in access in 2016 to provide higher speeds for our customers such that it will give us a better opportunity to gain in those customers.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So really, the outlook for cash taxes is the same as it was last quarter. Basically, our most current information is that we really believe bonus depreciation is clearly on the radar of congressional leaders. The House Ways and Means Committee cleare
componenttext: Yes. So really, the outlook for cash taxes is the same as it was last quarter. Basically, our most current information is that we really believe bonus depreciation is clearly on the radar of congressional leaders. The House Ways and Means Committee cleared legislation, making 50% bonus depreciation part of the permanent Tax Court incentive finance committee, included a 2-year extension of 50% bonus retroactive to '15 and '16 with their extenders package. So we believe the extenders package is going to move along, and we really think that the incentive staff has been pretty outspoken to our people in terms of getting bonus depreciation issues. So we feel more comfortable that will have bonus depreciation in '15 and '16 than we did last quarter. And we felt pretty good about it then.

And the only reason I ask is if you were to receive a large amount of capital, you've got very little pre-payable target. So I just wanted to ask around the leverage target in general?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's one of the things we have to work through as we get further into the process. But our target is really still about 3x. Remember, we have said that we would allow that to drift up, just if EBITDA deteriorates and we see EBITDA turning, around out to
componenttext: That's one of the things we have to work through as we get further into the process. But our target is really still about 3x. Remember, we have said that we would allow that to drift up, just if EBITDA deteriorates and we see EBITDA turning, around out to ultimately bringing the leverage back down. So we wouldn't be really held by a rating more or less in terms of keeping our EBITDA within our weighted range. But we'll just determine once we get closer to the execution over the opportunity on the data centers as to where we might go with the proceeds there.

componenttext: Thank you, Said. Overall, we believe we have the best portfolio of assets we've ever had at the company. Now it's really about execution.
